Card1.title: Paper 1 - Multiple-choice
Card1.p: Multiple-choice questions Questions will be based on all syllabus content Externally assessed

Card2.title: Paper 2 - Structured Written Paper
Card2.p: Questions will be based on all syllabus content Externally assessed

Wrapper.title: Candidates study the following topics:
Wrapper.p:
The fundamentals of accounting 
 Sources and recording of data 
 Verification of accounting records 
 Accounting procedures 
 Preparation of financial statements 
 Analysis and interpretation 
 Accounting principles and policies

Card3.title: Paper 3: Theory (Core)
Card3.p: Short-answer and structured questions. Externally assessed

Card4.title: Paper 4: Theory (Extended)
Card4.p: Short-answer and structured questions. Externally assessed

Wrapper.title: Candidates study the following topics:
Wrapper.p:
Characteristics and classification of living organisms 
 Movement into and out of cells 
 Biological molecules 
 Enzymes 
 Plant/human nutrition 
 Transport in plants/animals 
 Diseases and immunity  
 Respiration  
 Excretion in humans  
 Coordination and response  
 Drugs  
 Reproduction  
 Inheritance  
 Organisms and their environment 
 Human influences on ecosystems 
 iotechnology and genetic modification

Card1.title: Paper 1 - Short Answer and Data Response
Card1.p: Four questions requiring a mixture of short answers and structured data responses. Candidates answer all questions. Externally assessed

Card2.title: Paper 2 - Case Study
Card2.p: Four questions based on a case study, provided as an insert with the paper. Candidates answer all questions. Externally assessed

Wrapper.title: Candidates study the following topics:
Wrapper.p:
Understanding business activity 
 People in business 
 Marketing 
 Operations management 
 Financial information and decisions 
 External influences on business activity

Card3.title: Paper 3: Theory (Core)
Card3.p: Short-answer and structured questions. Externally assessed

Card4.title: Paper 4: Theory (Extended)
Card4.p: Short-answer and structured questions. Externally assessed

Wrapper.title: Candidates study the following topics:
Wrapper.p:
States of matter  
 Atoms, elements and compounds 
 Stoichiometry 
 Electrochemistry 
 Chemical energetics 
 Chemical reactions 
 Acids, bases and salts 
 The Periodic Table 
 Metals 
 Chemistry of the environment 
 Organic chemistry  
 Experimental techniques and chemical analysis

Card1.title: Paper 1 - Computer Systems
Card1.p: Short-answer and structured questions. Questions will be based on Topics 1–6 of the subject content. All questions are compulsory. No calculators are permitted. Externally assessed

Card2.title: Paper 2 - Algorithms, Programming and Logic
Card2.p: Short-answer and structured questions and a scenario-based question. Questions will be based on Topics 7–10 of the subject content. All questions are compulsory. No calculators are permitted. Externally assessed

Wrapper.title: Candidates study the following topics:
Wrapper.p:
Computer systems 
 Data representation 
 Data transmission  
 Hardware  
 Software  
 The internet and its uses  
 Automated and emerging technologies   
 Algorithm design and problem-solving  
 Programming 
 Databases  
 Boolean logic

Card1.title: Paper 1- Multiple Choice
Card1.p: Candidates answer all 30 questions Externally assessed

Card2.title: Paper 2 - Structured Questions
Card2.p: Candidates answer one compulsory question and three questions from a choice of four. Externally assessed

Wrapper.title: Candidates study the following topics:
Wrapper.p:
The basic economic problem 
 The allocation of resources 
 Microeconomic decision makers 
 Government and the macroeconomy 
 Economic development 
 International trade and globalisation

Card1.title: Paper 1 - Reading
Card1.p: Structured and extended writing questions. Questions will be based on three reading texts. Externally assessed

Card2.title: Paper 2 - Directed Writing and Composition
Card2.p: Extended writing question and a composition task. Externally assessed

Wrapper.title: Cambridge IGCSE First Language English offers candidates the opportunity to
Wrapper.p:
respond with understanding to a rich array of reading texts during the course as a whole 
 use these texts to inform and inspire their own writing, and write in a range of text types for different purposes and audiences.  
 develop both their speaking and their listening skills, delivering a presentation, and responding to questions and engaging in conversations.  
 become appreciative and critical readers, writers, speakers and listeners.

Card1.title: Paper 1 -Theory
Card1.p: Section A: short and structured questions. Section B: short-answer and extended response questions based on source material. Externally assessed

Card2.title: Paper 2 - Management in context
Card2.p: Short, and extended response questions based on source material. Externally assessed

Wrapper.title: Candidates study the following topics:
Wrapper.p:
Rocks and minerals and their exploitation 
 Energy and the environment  
 Agriculture and the environment  
 Water and its management  
 Oceans and fisheries 
 Managing natural hazards 
 The atmosphere and human activities 
 Human population 
 Natural ecosystems and human activities.

Card1.title: Paper 1 - Listening
Card1.p: Candidates listen to a number of recordings and answer multiple-choice and matching questions. Externally assessed

Card2.title: Paper 2 - Reading
Card2.p: Candidates read a number of texts and answer multiple-choice and matching questions as well as questions requiring short answers. Externally assessed

Card3.title: Paper 3 -  Speaking
Card3.p: Candidates complete one role play and conversations on two topics. Internally assessed and externally moderated

Card4.title: Paper 4 - Writing
Card4.p: Candidates complete one form-filling task, one directed writing task and one task in the format of an email/letter or article/blog. Externally assessed

Wrapper.title: Candidates study the following topics:
Wrapper.p:
Everyday activities  
 Personal and social life  
 The world around us  
 The world of work  
 The international world

Card1.title: Paper 1 - Geographical Themes
Card1.p: Candidates answer three questions, each worth 25 marks. Candidates must answer one question from each section. Externally assessed

Card2.title: Paper 2 - Geographical Skills
Card2.p: Candidates answer all the questions. Externally assessed

Card3.title: Component 3 Coursework
Card3.p: Teachers set one centre-based assignment of up to 2000 words. Centre-based assessment

Card4.title: Paper 4 - Alternative to Coursework
Card4.p: Candidates answer two compulsory questions, completing a series of written tasks. Externally assessed

Wrapper.title: Candidates study the following topics:
Wrapper.p:
Theme 1: Population and settlement  
 Theme 2: The natural environment 
 Theme 3: Economic development

Card1.title: Paper 1 - Listening
Card1.p: Candidates listen to a number of recordings and answer multiple-choice and matching questions. Externally assessed

Card2.title: Paper 2 - Reading
Card2.p: Candidates read a number of texts and answer multiple-choice and matching questions as well as questions requiring short answers. Externally assessed

Card3.title: Paper 3 - Speaking
Card3.p: Candidates complete one role play and conversations on two topics. Internally assessed and externally moderated

Card4.title: Paper 4 - Writing
Card4.p: Candidates complete one form-filling task, one directed writing task and one task in the format of an email/letter or article/blog. Externally assessed

Wrapper.title: Candidates study the following topics:
Wrapper.p:
Everyday activities 
 Personal and social life 
 The world around us  
 The world of work  
 The international world

Card1.title: Paper 1 - Written paper
Card1.p: Candidates answer two questions from Section A (Core Content) and one question from Section B (Depth Studies). All questions are in the form of structured essays, split into three parts: (a), (b) and (c). Externally assessed

Card2.title: Paper 2 - Written paper
Card2.p: Candidates answer six questions on one prescribed topic taken from the Core Content. There is a range of source material relating to each prescribed topic. The prescribed topic changes in each examination session – see section 4. Externally assessed

Card3.title: Component 3 Coursework
Card3.p: Candidates produce one piece of extended writing based on a Depth Study from the syllabus or a Depth Study devised by the Centre. Internally assessed/externally moderated

Card4.title: Paper 4 - Alternative to Coursework - Written paper
Card4.p: Candidates answer one question on a Depth Study. Externally assessed

Wrapper.title: Candidates study the following topics:
Wrapper.p:
Option A: 
 The nineteenth century: the development of modern nation states, 1848–1914 
      Option B 
 The twentieth century: international relations since 1919 
 In addition, all candidates must also study at least one of the following Depth Studies

Wrapper.title: Candidates study the following topics:
Wrapper.p:
Number 
 Algebra 
 Alebra and graphs 
 Coordinate geometry 
 Shape and space 
 Geometry 
 Mensuration 
 Trigonometry 
 Vectors and transformations 
 Probability and statistics

Card3.title: Paper 3: Theory (Core)
Card3.p: Short-answer and structured questions. Externally assessed

Card4.title: Paper 4: Theory (Extended)
Card4.p: Short-answer and structured questions. Externally assessed

Wrapper.title: Candidates study the following topics:
Wrapper.p:
Motion, forces and energy 
 Thermal physics 
 Waves 
 Electricity and magnetism 
 Nuclear physics 
 Space physics

Card1.title: Paper 1
Card1.p: Candidates answer one compulsory data response question and one optional structured question from a choice of two. Externally assessed

Card2.title: Paper 2
Card2.p: Candidates answer two optional structured questions from a choice of four. Externally assessed

Wrapper.title: Candidates study the following topics:
Wrapper.p:
Unit 1: Theory and methods  
 Unit 2: Culture, identity and socialisation  
 Unit 3: Social inequality  
 Unit 4: Family  
 Unit 5: Education  
 Unit 6: Crime, deviance and social control  
 Unit 7: Media
